Fields.DialogueText: Augusta? I got your... invitation? What is all this?
Oh! Captain, darling, simply lovely that you could make it. I've been planning this cotillion since I joined the fleet! Just a little way to bring so many lovely folk together, don't you think?
Cotillion? What? Wait, how many officers are here? This looks like half the fleet.
Oh, well, of course, darling. I wouldn't dream of anything less. My poor sisters can't attend, but simply anyone else who is anyone is here.
How did you organize this? And without consulting me? There is a war going on.
Oh, boo, Captain. I did consult you. You have your invitation right there, don't you? You'd hardly be let in without it.

Fields.MenuText: This is a tremendous waste of resources and time that should have gone towards the war effort.
I'm not really much for fancy parties. I think I'll head back to my quarters.
So is this black tie? I didn't really read the invitation that well. I could change, or I can just grab a drink and mingle.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, pshaw, Captain. What's the point of having a war if we can't simply take some time to smell the roses? Do smell them, by the way. It's what they're here for.
Oh, honey, don't be like that. It's not every day this much power and commanding presence is assembled in one place.
Well, I for one love an officer in uniform, so why don't you just sidle on over to the bar and get yourself something nice, sugar?
Scratch that, there's the alarm. It looks like fancy parties are going to have to wait for the war, after all.
Ooooooo, drat. Right when you finally arrived, Captain.
You heard the Captain, boys and girls. Please pass your dishes back to the valets.
Then, if y'all would kindly mosey back to your action stations, we'll have a chat with those girls about ruining my get-together.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I'm sorry about your party. It seemed like you put a lot of effort into it.
Oh, sweetie, the cotillion? That's nice of you to say, but these things happen. One must simply meet adversity with grace and humility.
If you say so. What does that entail in this circumstance? It must be hard to get people together during wartime.
Oh, it surely is, but one does what one must. In fact, many of these poor folk are so thin you can't even see their shadow. Someone has to feed them.
Well, that's a noble endeavour, and I certainly support it.
And their manners are just atrocious. I do declare, I'm not one to speak ill of others, but someone needs to keep order around here.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like an uphill battle. I think most of the sailors take pride in being crude.
I hope you succeed, I'd like to see more decorum around the place.
You better not be trying to make me into a high society type. I don't do well with fanciness.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I do tend to get my way, Captain. I am quite the charmer.
Wouldn't it be lovely? They're sweethearts, but it seems like they've only got one oar in the water, sometimes.
Mhm, Captain? Well, I've certainly heard that before. We'll see what you have to say when I'm through.
Anyway, we don't have time for that right now. The fleet is moving towards an engagement.
Ah, I'll tell the loves to get to their stations.
@BATTLE
Something the matter, sugar? You look edgier than a long-tailed cat in a room full of rocking chairs.
Ah, Augusta, I didn't see you there. I was just concerned. There's been a lot of Morgana activity in the area, but we can't seem to pinpoint the enemy fleets.
Oh, honey, is that all? Why, that's nothing that a little dinner wouldn't fix. Let me get the chef to put something together for the officers.
I'm not sure food is going to help us resolve a phantom fleet, but I appreciate the offer.
Nonsense! You're so skinny that if you turned sideways and stuck out your tongue, you'd look like a zipper. Now come along and and dress up for mealtime.

Fields.MenuText: This still feels like a waste of time... but I suppose I am hungry.
Well, I certainly can't say no to that, and I did miss out on your last meal.
Would you stop trying to get me to dress up? My uniform is fine.

Fields.DialogueText: With an attitude like that, Captain, you can starve for all I care. Of all the ungrateful...
And what a shame that was! The meal was cold by the time the battle ended.
As much as I love a well-cut figure in uniform, it is a bit less than stylish, if I do say so myself.
It looks like it's a moot point anyway. At least one fleet has been spotted.
Drat. One of these days, Captain. When we don't have these uppity girls breathing down our necks.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, Captain, there you are. Would you be a dear and go tell that stick in the mud of a Yankee who quartermasters our fleet to stop being so stingy?
Interestingly enough, Augusta, I have a report from the quartermaster that your "constant demands for esoteric supplies present a major logistics issue."
Well, obviously, that's simply slander. I am nothing if not humble and practical, a picture of self-reliance.
It looks like you requested five "overstuffed" arm chairs, a humidor of cigars, and what appears to be a brandy that stopped production years ago.
Well, Captain, clearly any ship without a smoking lounge is ill suited to host a gala of any magnitude, though one struggles on.
These are definitely unreasonable requests. It says here that you wanted live parrots?
I thought they'd make lovely party favors. And they accentuate the nautical theme in simply fabulous ways.

Fields.MenuText: You're a boat!
These demands for unnecessary supplies have to stop. We have a hard enough time resupplying as it is.
You know what? I'll talk to the quartermaster. I really want to see where you go with this.

Fields.DialogueText: How dare you, Captain? I am a lady!
You're just as bad as that dreadful quartermaster. He squeezes a quarter so tight the eagle screams.
Ah, aren't you just a peach? Isn't everything so much better when I have my way?
I can hear the alarm. We'll have to talk about this later. Get your crew ready.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hello, Augusta - I was hoping you could help me with... where did you get all of these penguins?
Oh, hello, Captain! You're just in time! I'm training these little fellows to do a routine that will lift the crew's spirits.
But where? Where did you get penguins? And trained penguins, at that?
Oh, we've been in the southern hemisphere enough that they aren't too hard to find. And it's amazing what one can achieve by asking nicely.
And they're trained to dance? I'm sorry, I'm just still confused.
No, no, I am training them to dance. Among other things. Jeromy, that is not how one holds a shrimp fork! Put it down!

Fields.MenuText: But... why? Why does any of this make sense?
So what are they going to do? I assume it'll be amusing, at the very least.
It just occured to me that I'm talking to a lovely woman who is also a boat and I should stop worrying too much.

Fields.DialogueText: Well they have little tuxedos, obviously, so they're already dressed for a formal dinner.
For now, a nice little song and dance number, but I think I can get them to serve hors d'oeuvres.
That's right, sugar. Why don't you mosey on and come back when you remember what you need help with, hmm?
Oh, that's the alarm. I guess you'll have to work on your routine later.
Of course. You fellows be good and clean up while Momma is gone. I'm looking at you, Jeromy.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Augusta, there you are. You aren't... busy with anything right now, are you? I don't want to interrupt.
No, I was simply enjoying a moment in quiet repose, as one is wont to do from time to time.
All right, fair enough. I need your help with something. I'm still trying to pin down that phantom fleet. And I need more than food this time.
Well, you didn't exactly get food last time, so let me call the mess. Then, why don't you show me what you have so far?
You really don't have to do that... but, sure.
Time passes...
As you can see, we've had sightings of them along the coast here, as well as by a few of these settlements.
And you, of course, have evidence that these are the same ships in each instance?
Yes, we've got positive identification on all of them.

Fields.MenuText: Where do you think they might have a base? Or just a preferred staging area?
Do you have any ideas about how they might be managing to strike this large of an area?
I'm not even sure what I'm looking for yet, but I was hoping you'd have some insight.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... it looks like they're hitting the less populated areas here a bit more than they should.
They aren't following the same routes we are. It looks like they don't have the same old maps as we do.
You know, I think I do, but I'd like to look over this intelligence just a bit more before I assert a theory.
That's the alarm. Looks like we'll have more information soon. I'll leave the maps with you. For now, it's time for action stations.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Augusta, where have you been? You were out of formation for hours!
A lady has her secrets, Captain. And I needed to work on a few little pet projects.
You could have been attacked in that time, and then what would you have done?
Oh no, sugar, I wasn't in any danger. But we do only have about half an hour before those dreadful girls spring an ambush.
What are you talking about? The Morganas?
There's a fleet steaming up from the south, hoping to catch us by surprise. I recommend we turn to face them soon.

Fields.MenuText: How do you know this? It's not like they use running lights.
All right, but we're having some serious words after this. I don't want to have to worry about missing ships.
Make it so, and give me their disposition.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, honey, that seems like the sort of question one should ask after one survives an ambush.
Oh, honey, you should know I have everything under control. I simply wish to help my folks.
Right away, Captain.
All right, let's show the Morganas they can't sneak up on us.
Of course, sweetie. You're welcome, by the way.
@BATTLE
All right, Augusta, now we really should talk. Do you want to tell me what you were doing off by yourself earlier?
Oh sweetie, I would. Really, I would. But I surely won't.
This isn't the time for games, Augusta. We have a war to fight, and I need to know I can trust the people under my command.
This is the perfect time for games, sweetie. You are speaking like someone who has never fought a concerted campaign of information warfare before.
I'm sorry, what was that? What are you doing out there?
Honey, if I told you, I would have to kill you. Only joking, darling. Probably.

Fields.MenuText: You know I could just interrogate your crew, right?
Can you at least try to keep me in the loop as much as possible? This war is stressful enough.
All right, I trust you. Keep up the good work.

Fields.DialogueText: Try it and I'll jerk the knot out of your tail.
Oh, of course, darling. I'll make sure you know everything you need to know.
Don't I always, sweetie?
Incidentally, the Morganas are probably waiting for us in the strait up ahead, since we trounced them earlier.
I'll inform the fleet.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, if you're here to complain about the penguin... deposits everywhere, you can go on your merry way, as I have seen to it.
Yes, I've seen the dog with the mop, and I'm not interested in asking about how you trained him to do that.
Oh, it was very easy. One simply has to be very clear about what one wants and provide lots of encouragement.
Not interested. I wanted to know about the man with no clearance who has been wandering around demanding to measure officers.
Harold? He's harmless, darling. And he's acting at my behest; I simply had to do something about the state of the crew.
We have officers from a half dozen or more nations, and sailors from more than a score. Until the Protection Fleet gets their act together, we need uniforms to foster unity.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure what the officers and sailors will think about that. They do all have their own allegiances.
It would be useful to have uniforms to tie everything together.
This seems like a waste of time. We've all got something to wear right now, and we have bigger things to worry about.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, please, I'm not advocating secession. And I'll be sure to leave a little space for something to indicate the country of origin.
I certainly thought so, and what better place to start than the officers, hmm? One has to set an example, after all.
That's why I'm worrying about it, Captain. Now you take that pretty little head of yours back to running the fleet, and leave the important things to me.
There's the alarm. It looks like we're going to have to play dress-up later.
Captain, I'm going to seat you next to a flatulent Soviet at my next dinner.
@BATTLE
A tiny penguin just delivered a letter to my door, inviting me to your next party.
Aren't they just a delight? I'm so glad he made it. They have such trouble with stairs.
Technically, he delivered someone else's invitation, but that's not why I'm here.
Oh, that is dreadful. I know they can't read, but this could be devastating for the seating charts. The poor dears.
You can't let wild animals wander around on the ship. They could get underfoot or be trampled, and who knows what will happen in a battle?
Oh, no one would dare step on my little helpers. They're such little sweethearts, and so useful for passing messages.

Fields.MenuText: Why are you using penguins as a messaging service on a warship?
Why are you building a menagerie on an active combat vessel?
This seems like it is starting to get out of hand, but I don't want to involve myself in whatever mad scheme you are currently concocting.

Fields.DialogueText: So I can order food to my room without breaking radio silence. Honestly, have you never run a campaign of misdirection before?
Because there's a war on, obviously. Otherwise I'd be doing it on the preeminent ambassador of the fleet.
I promise I'll keep you informed if I decide to bring in anything larger than a nice quarter horse.
I have never been happier to hear the alarm. Let's go fight a naval war with live ships that hate us.
I'd almost be insulted if that wasn't one of the nicest things you have asked me to do, Captain. Maybe there's hope for you yet.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And, Captain, that was the Japanese ambassador to Norway. And over there, you can just see the archbishop behind the buffet table.
I'm still not sure how you got this many people to show up for a party in the middle of the ocean in the middle of two wars.
A woman has her ways, dear. No one would dare turn down an invitation from me. It would be social suicide.
Oh, drat, there's the alarm. All right, everyone! Please set your plates down and then proceed to the portholes so you can view the Morgana fleet!
What are you doing? These are civilians and we need to get them to safety!
Sugar, I am safety. Why don't you button your lip and start commanding the fleet like a good Captain?

Fields.MenuText: We should never have put these civilians in danger in the first place.
As long as you take responsibility for their safety. I can't have that hanging over me.
You knew this would happen, didn't you? What game are you playing?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, how very wrong you are, sweetie. Now run along and let Momma handle this.
Of course! A good hostess would never let her guests be blown to smithereens.
All you need to mind is that I'm playing to win, honey. Now why don't you get going?
All right, everyone, I'll have drinks around shortly. If you'll excuse me, I must fight a war for a bit.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well, that party was nerve-wracking. I'm glad it's over.
What are you talking about? I thought the party was splendid. It ended rather well, even with the small altercation.
I just had to fight a battle with your hold stuffed full of dignitaries. It was nerve-wracking because I didn't want them to die.
Oh, you were worried about me! That's so sweet of you, but you really shouldn't.
I was worried you were going to explode and support for the Fleet would collapse overnight.
Really, it's okay to say it out loud. I do know the effect I have on others.

Fields.MenuText: You are reckless, and you're playing with the lives of yourself, your crew, and the people of this fleet.
I'm done talking to you. I have no idea how to deal with this behavior.
I really liked the little ties you put on the penguins. They weren't excellent waiters, though.

Fields.DialogueText: Everything's a game, Captain. And everything's a gamble. But I keep winning.
I certainly prefer that you passively enable it to some of the other alternatives, so I approve.
Why, of course they were! I trained them to take orders patiently, and then bring whomever ordered something a mint julep. And they did that splendidly.
Ah, look, the alarm is going off. Time to go fight that war, is it not, Captain?
All right, but we really need to talk about this some more.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I've had it up to here with you, Augusta. In the time you were gone, we just missed three different run-ins with the Morganas.
Had it up to where, Captain? Can you show me on a map?
What? No, I can't, it's just an expression. The point is that you've been absent without any kind of leave again.
Oh, I see. I simply asked because I can pinpoint the three most likely bases of operation for the Morganas on this map.
Wait, you can do what? How did you find that out?
Oh, whoopsie, silly me. I mean I already pinpointed them. Here you go, Captain; give this a nice once-over.
And incidentally, I can't tell you how, because then you'll stop it, and then they'll stop it, and then we'll lose a major method of tracking them.

Fields.MenuText: That actually makes a lot of sense, but I'd feel better if you told me regardless.
All right, I get it, I'm better off not knowing. I can live with that.
I am the captain, and I need to know anything and everything I can about how the Morganas operate.

Fields.DialogueText: And I'd feel better on the riverbank in Savannah drinking mint juleps.
I am pleased to hear that, Captain, because you'll certainly have to.
With all due respect, Captain, go sit on a sewing needle.
In the meantime, we're looking at a fleet moving in from the northeast in the next hour, so I'd recommend preparing.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Augusta, something strange has been going on around here lately.
I can assure you that I have not brought anything aboard that you should be able to detect.
I'm breezing right past that. What I'm here about is actually that our latest supply shipments contained everything we requested.
Lovely! I'm glad to hear that our needs are being taken seriously.
We have never had a supply shipment without shortages. Ever. I'm starting to think that you had something to do with this, given your ways.
Please, Captain, a lady never tells. Although, one could posit that perhaps a few firsthand accounts made their way back to the mainland in one form or another.

Fields.MenuText: You staged a battle in front of those dignitaries just to make our case to the rest of the world.
I'm not asking, but I wanted to let you know I appreciate it.
I don't think I approve of your recklessness, but I can't argue with the results.

Fields.DialogueText: I staged nothing, and saying I did is slander. A girl can't be expected to know everything, hmm?
Well, that is lovely to hear, darling. I do declare, I wish everyone could be so grateful.
That's why I get them, Captain. It does a lady no good to argue.
Well, it looks like we'll be putting those supplies to use soon. We're advancing on one of the possible bases you found.
Delightful! I do hope we get it right the first time.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, Captain. There is an inlet into that bay around the northern edge that we may be able to sneak a few ships through.
Ignoring how you know that, won't those ships be cut off, especially if we find the Morgana fleet in open waters?
You'd think that, but the inlet doubles as an escape route. If we can press the Morganas back, we can link up with the flanking fleet.
And if the Morganas try to break out? What happens then?
Then they break out away from the flanking fleet and through us. And the flankers become their tail and chase them out.
And if the Morganas focus on the flanking fleet instead of us?
Then we take advantage of their foolishness and grind them into a fine powder. It seems simple enough.

Fields.MenuText: That does seem like a sound plan to me. I'll let the other ships know.
I'm going to run this past the rest of the tactics team, but I don't see any problems with it.
I didn't know you were this much of a tactician, Augusta.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I already did. Don't you worry none, sugar, Momma has it all figured out.
I briefed them already, and they had a few good points I've already incorporated.
This isn't tactics, hun; it's just misdirection and reading the room. Which just happens to be a skill of mine.
All right, then. To battle we go.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Good news and bad news, Augusta. Which one do you want first?
The good news is that we destroyed a Morgana fleet sheltering in the bay, and the bad news is that it was the wrong fleet, according to the boys in intelligence.
How did you know that?
Inadequately disguised ship-to-ship radio broadcasts, obviously.
What?
Don't worry about it, darling! What's important is I don't have your RSVP for my soiree yet.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I thought I gave it to the penguin, but if I need to I can just tell you in person. I was a little iffy on the formal wear, however.
You don't get to just blow it off like that. Have you been spying on our own communications?
I told you, I'm not really big on fancy things. Also, I'm on the ship. Shouldn't it be assumed I can come?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, those silly birds. But I will accept this as your formal RSVP and have your suit ready with plenty of time.
So is that a yes? I'll just put you down as a yes. Don't worry, I'll have a suit ready for you.
The RSVP is a politeness to the hostess, so she knows how to seat the guests and how much food to prepare. Do try not to embarrass me there.
Oh, look at the time! I do believe we'll be hearing the alarm any minute now.
I know you planned this somehow. I'm just not sure how.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, Captain, you really must try these canapes. They're delectable. The chef has really outdone himself.
Augusta, we're nearing the second site. I think there are drills you should be running, rather than sitting here eating.
How dare you! I am not eating, I am tasting! Everything must be just right, you understand.
I'm not sure I do understand. We've got a major battle coming up, and you're worried about a party.
Of course! It would be a terrible shame if I threw a miserable or, shudder to think of it, boring party.
I'm just saying, shouldn't you be busy with something else?
Captain, I'm surprised at you! Forgive my vulgarity, but I am busier than a one-legged man at a butt kicking contest.

Fields.MenuText: I've learned not to ask questions at this point, so I'm just going to trust you.
What are you busy with, exactly? There doesn't seem to be that much going on here.
Busy tasting instead of preparing for the upcoming battles.

Fields.DialogueText: You're becoming so well trained. Do take a candy on the way out, Captain.
Captain! I have been having words with my dressmaker, I've had to create a system of radio encryption from scratch, and the penguins are falling in with bad influences from other ships.
Prepare all you like for the battle, Captain, but I am making headway in the war.
All right, well, we should reach the second site soon.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, Augusta. What are your thoughts on how we should form up for battle in there?
We need to come about and prepare for a breakout as soon as possible. They'll try to trap us in the mouth of the bay.
What about the ships in the bay? Why are we even sailing in if they have a trap planned?
To spring the trap, of course. They wouldn't go through all of this trouble to prepare for us if they were expecting us to be ready.
And there shouldn't be any ships in the bay itself. It gets shallow too quickly, so we simply need to enter and then turn about immediately.
And I assume once the misdirection part is over with, it's up to me to decide all those tedious tactics.
That is what you're good for after all, sweetheart.

Fields.MenuText: We really need to have a talk about keeping this information to yourself for so long.
Well, I'm glad you left something for me to do. All right, give me their disposition and I'll plan the breakout.
I chose to continue my campaign of blissful ignorance. But I am happy we're the ones springing the trap now.

Fields.DialogueText: We can talk about whatever you like, sugar, but it's not going to change very much.
Right you are, Captain. I'm excited to give the Morganas another taste of their own medicine.
I do love to be the bringer of good news, Captain.
All right, people, we have a sucker punch to throw.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, Captain, I have such delightful news! I'm sure you'll be as excited as I.
Let me guess, the uniforms for the officers have arrived?
Oh boo, Captain. Ruining my surprise like that. Did you see them being loaded on?
No, a herd of penguins forced me out of my cabin while a couple of boys from the mess staff brought them in.
Technically, I believe they are actually a waddle of penguins if they are being active and not at sea. Or perhaps a raft; we are on a boat, after all.
I don't care about the naming practices of penguins, wherever they may be located.

Fields.MenuText: In fact, I'm most concerned about how anyone got into my quarters in the first place, especially birds.
I really want to know how you determined my size when I've never sat for a fitting.
I want to know why you're turning this boat into a place where I have to ask so many questions about penguins.

Fields.DialogueText: Please, you're not always the best at cleaning up after yourself. How do you think the custodial staff obtains entry?
I am an excellent judge of these things. And that is all you should probably know about it.
Because, darling, every day you don't learn something is a day wasted.
I don't have any say in any of what's happening, do I? Just to be clear.
Of course not! If it makes you feel better, you never did. Oh, there's the alarm; we should get to it.
@BATTLE
Is everything okay up here, Augusta? I heard gunfire.
Oh, nothing is wrong, sweetie. I was just letting the penguins swim. Oh, there's another one.
*BANG*
Are you shooting sharks? Why are you shooting sharks? I'm so confused.
Well, I shot the first one to protect my little darlings, and then the blood attracted the others. To make a long story short, we're having shark at the next party.
Are the penguins okay? That can't be a healthy place for a penguin to be.
Oh, they're fine. They're having a lovely time. And I obviously haven't missed yet.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think I'll ever underestimate you again. And... shark does sound tasty.
Can you shoot that one? I don't like his face and I think he might be planning to eat us when we sink.
This seems like the sort of activity that I should take umbrage with with, but I'm not going to get involved.

Fields.DialogueText: I know how to treat my guests, especially when they're coming all this way to see little old me.
Mmm, well spotted, sweetie. Let me take care of him for you.
Mmhmm, darling. I'll have everything cleaned up before you know it.
We'll be ready here in a bit, so get them back aboard. We've got a fleet engagement coming up.
All right. Come back aboard, babies! We have a brawl to get to.
@BATTLE
Where have you been? Do I even want to know at this point?
Oh, honey, of course you do! I have the entire disposition of the enemy fleet in the upcoming engagement.
And how did you pull that off, dare I ask? Do I even want to know?
You still have a burr in your saddle, don't you? All right, I suppose I can let you in on one of my little secrets.
I've been skirting the enemy fleet with the engines off and spotting for their disposition. And, obviously, I cracked their communications.
You've been doing what?
What? It's not like I was in any danger. We haven't even been close to being spotted.

Fields.MenuText: That's incredibly dangerous, as I'm sure you're aware. I presume I don't have any say in the matter?
I'd actually presumed it was something like that. Not to that level, of course, but I trusted you were up to something helpful.
And here I thought you were sneaking off to the mainland to visit the local nightlife.

Fields.DialogueText: It's only dangerous for those who might be caught. And I dare you to presume I might be caught.
Well, of course I'd never do something to endanger the fleet. I do so care about my boys.
Slander, Captain, pure slander. I bring the nightlife to me. What do you take me for?
Very well. Let's start pushing through their defenses.
@BATTLE
Honestly, these ones aren't very smart.
Come on, Captain - we need to clear these last few monsters out of the ocean before the guests arrive.
In fairness, I wouldn't expect the guests even to approach until these things were gone.
But it's just not right to make them wait. No, the Morganas have to go right this minute!
I wasn't exactly challenging that point.
@BATTLE
All right, the guests are beginning to arrive. If you boys would be so good as to get those chairs moved, and if you wouldn't mind setting the tables...
How are the preparations coming? I think I've got the tactical plan drawn up, so we should be good to go.
Ah, lovely, Captain! I'm sure you will put on a show for our guests. The shark fin soup is cooking now, and one of the Japanese admirals is donating a chef to prepare the rest.
Good to hear it. I'm glad things are going according to your plan.

Fields.MenuText: I'm still not sure inviting a group of dignitaries to a battle is a good idea, but it seemed to work before.
I'm trusting your judgment on this, even if it does scare me a little bit. You're sure this will be fine?
I'm washing my hands of all of this and just letting you take your course.

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, darling, I know what I'm doing. Nothing helps a struggling group like a little patronism.
Of course I'm sure, sugar. I know exactly what I'm doing, and we'll all come out of this better than before.
That is usually the safest option, hun. Just follow along as best you can.
Now be a dear and go change into that uniform I had made for you, will you? You are going to look darling at the dinner.
All right, but I'm still not sure how you convinced me to do this. Do you need anything else before I go?
No, sweetie. Now be a good Captain and run along. I just saw a Japanese ambassador I can only assume is dying to meet me.
*ALARM*
How are you liking the party, Captain? Is the food agreeing with you? I do hope you've tried the punch.
I have a hard time relaxing when I'm heading into an active combat zone. I'm not exactly looking forward to this battle, even if you are.
It'll be fine, truly. All you have to do is put on a nice show and dig out a heavily fortified fleet with a lot of cover from a harbor they're in complete control of.
Oh, it's almost time for your speech!
My what?
Attention! Attention, everyone! Our esteemed Captain would like to make a brief speech on the eve of another great battle for our world.
My fellow... humans! Thank you, for coming here. I am honored to see so many of you put aside your differences in a time of turmoil, to come together today.

Fields.MenuText: I am a soldier first and foremost, and I am here to do a job. The Morganas threaten our existence, and I will see them eradicated.
When we fall upon the enemy, I will show you the full fury that our fleet can bring to bear against these monsters that plague us.
We are humans, beset by monsters. And it going to take each and every one of us to push those monsters back into the dark from whence they came.

Fields.DialogueText: Very nice, Captain. Very strong and passionate. I think you won some of them over.
Very warlike, Captain. I think some of these bumpkins might understand we're fighting a war here now.
I think that will go well with the show we are about to put on, Captain.
Now if you would kindly take a look out the portholes, the Captain and I have prepared a fireworks display.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
They're trying to reform by that reef, Captain!
We'll show them no quarter.
Man the guns and let's drive these last few out!
@BATTLE
Very nicely done, Captain. Quite the show we put on for our guests, wouldn't you say? Really lit a fire under them.
I still don't like having civilians aboard. We chose to be here; we know the risks. They're just tourists.
Come now, they'll be gone soon enough. And they weren't all bad, were they?

Fields.MenuText: Well, it was nice to see a few faces from the old country. I didn't know any of them personally, but they seemed to know me.
The sooner I'm out of this "fleet" uniform and back in my old one, the happier I'll be. This charade is tiresome.
I'm just glad to see the back of them. They have no place in battle or on my ships.

Fields.DialogueText: It seems you're quite the person to know these days, hmm? Imagine your marriage prospects now.
And after all the sweat and tears my man put into the design. Truly, Captain, you're an ungrateful sot.
I know, sweetie, but Momma has a war to win, and we need to show people of consequence that we're fighting.
That doesn't change the fact that every single person who set foot on your deck risked their lives without even understanding it.
It wouldn't have worked if they had understood. Trust me, everything will work out for the best.
I don't have very much of a choice, do I?
Augusta, the strangest thing happened. I'm not sure I believe it.
Ireland and Sweden have agreed to contribute more ships to the fleet.
Ireland and Sweden? How do you know that?
I pointed out the ambassadors at the gala, didn't I? They were most impressed with your work, darling.
Well did you know that Germany and Japan-
Signed a further agreement to donate a large portion of their industrial complex to increasing our available armament and maintenance supplies?
How did you know that?
I cornered the Japanese chief of the Navy by the hors d'oeuvres. "Oh Admiral Osami Nagano, I have so very many guns. If only someone could help me... fire them."
You're a real piece of work, you know that?
I think you mean "Thank you, Augusta, you've once again singlehandedly saved the fleet and secured the freedom and safety of every living soul on planet Earth."

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you're on our side. If you weren't, we'd lose in a day. So yes, thank you for keeping us safe.
Thank you, Augusta. I cannot imagine what it would be like trying to walk this road without doing so by your side.

Fields.DialogueText: What are friends for, Captain? Other than throwing the most delightful functions.
Anything, anytime, sugar. What lady is complete without a little arm candy?
